full_title_en: Mehran Score for Post-PCI Contrast Nephropathy
medium_description_en: Predicts risk of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

seo.meta_description_en: The Mehran Score for Post-PCI Contrast Nephropathy predicts risk of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

how_to_use.use_case_en: Use in patients undergoing PCI. Do not use in patients with pre-existing end-stage renal disease on dialysis or patients with contrast exposure within 1 week of the index procedure.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: In the original study, “contrast-induced nephropathy” was defined as an increase ≥0.5 mg/dL (or ≥25%) in pre-PCI serum creatinine at 48 hours post-PCI.

next_steps.advice_en: Consider renal protective measures such as N-acetylcysteine and limiting contrast volume in patients at high risk of CIN.

Note: the original study includes serum creatinine (as a dichotomous variable) as an alternative to eGFR, and adds 4 points for Cr >1.5 mg/dL. We have chosen to use eGFR in this calculator as it tends to be a more accurate measure of renal function than creatinine alone.

creator_info.about_en: Roxana Mehran, MD, FACC, FACP, FCCP, FESC, FAHA, FSCAI, is a professor in the department of medicine, cardiology, and population health science and policy at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. She is also the director of the Center for Interventional Cardiovascular Research and Clinical Trials at the Zena and Michael A. Wiener Cardiovascular Institute. Dr. Mehran’s primary research is focused on angioplasty and stent placement, cardiac catheterization, and acute coronary syndromes.
